title: Optimized protocol for quantifying 5' UTR-mediated translation initiation in S. cerevisiae using direct analysis of ribosome targeting
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
PCR amplification of the DNA pool
Timing: 2 days
Amplification of the designed DNA pool provides input material for subsequent in vitro transcription. We recommend optimizing the number of PCR cycles for each DNA pool to maximize yield while minimizing spurious overamplification products.
Resuspend the DNA pool to a final concentration of 0.5 ng/μL in 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0.
Prepare an 11× PCR master mix.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2163_14.csv
Aliquot 50 μL of PCR master mix into 11 individual PCR tubes. Place in thermocycler for 12 PCR cycles (or pre-determined optimal cycle number) as below:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2163_15.csv
Gel purify the amplified template DNA.
Cast two 8% non-denaturing TBE polyacrylamide mini gels.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Pool the PCR reactions and add 110 μL of 6× DNA loading dye.
Load the PCR product across all available lanes. Run the samples at 200 V for 50 min in 0.5× TBE.
Remove the gels from the plates and stain by covering in 15 mL of 0.5× TBE plus 2 μL of SYBR Gold.
Incubate at 25°C on a rocking platform for 5 min.
Visualize under blue light.
Note: An example pool PCR optimization gel is shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
Critical: The use of blue light illumination is necessary to prevent DNA damage that can result from UV illumination.
Excise PCR products with a razor blade and place gel slices into two 1.5 mL tubes containing 750 μL of DNA elution buffer.
Rotate for 12–14 h at 25°C.
Transfer the eluted DNA solution to new 1.5 mL tubes.
Add 750 μL of isopropanol and 2 μL of Glycoblue to each tube.
Vortex the sample and incubate at −20°C for at least 30 min.
Centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 30 min to pellet DNA.

Pause point: The purified DNA template can be stored at −20°C in isopropanol until ready for use.
Wash pellets with 750 μL of 70% ethanol and centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 10 min.
Remove supernatant and air-dry pellets at 25°C for 5 min.
Resuspend the precipitated DNA in 8 μL of nuclease-free water.

Timing: 2–3 days
This step generates the RNA pool to be used in the ribosome recruitment assay. Addition of the 5′ methylguanosine cap is required to emulate physiological cap-dependent translation. 3′ biotinylation ensures efficient RNA recovery after incubation in translation extract and fractionation.

Incubate the reaction at 37°C for 4 h.

Add 2 μL of TURBO DNase and incubate at 37°C for 15 min to degrade the template DNA.
Gel-purify the RNA pool by denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
Cast an 8% denaturing 1× TBE/7 M urea polyacrylamide mini gel. Pre-run the gel in 0.5× TBE at 200 V for 20 min.
Add 22 μL of 2× formamide buffer to the RNA and incubate at 70°C for 5 min to denature the RNA. Transfer the mixture to ice to cool.
Using a syringe, flush the wells of the mini gel with 0.5× TBE to remove urea.
Load 6 μL of denatured RNA per well. Run the gel at 200 V for 60 min.
Remove the gels from the plates and stain by covering in 15 mL of 0.5× TBE plus 2 μL of SYBR Gold.

Incubate at 25°C on a rocking platform for 5 min.
Visualize under blue light.

Rotate for 12–14 h at 4°C.
Transfer the eluted RNA solution to a new 1.5 mL tube for precipitation.
Add 750 μL of isopropanol and 2 μL of Glycoblue.
Vortex the sample and incubate at −20°C for at least 30 min. Centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 30 min to pellet RNA.
Pause point: The purified RNA can be stored at −20°C in isopropanol until ready for use.
Wash pellets with 750 μL of 80% ethanol and centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 10 min.
Remove supernatant and air-dry pellets at 25°C for 5 min.
Resuspend the precipitated RNA in 50 μL of nuclease-free water.
Transfer 0.5 μL of RNA to a tube containing 9.5 μL of water. Load 2 μL of diluted RNA onto a Nanodrop and measure concentration, targeting approximately 40 micrograms total.
Add 5′ methylguanosine cap as follows:
Add 2 μL of RNasin Plus to the 50 μL of purified RNA. Heat-denature by incubating at 65°C for 5 min. Transfer denatured RNA to ice for 2 min.
Prepare the capping reaction using the Vaccinia capping system (NEB).

Incubate the capping reaction at 37°C for 1 h.
Clean-up the capping reaction.
Critical: Keep the samples on ice for the duration of the reaction clean-up.
Add 560 μL of binding buffer and 640 μL of isopropanol to the capping reaction.

Apply 800 μL (maximum loading capacity) of the RNA solution to a Zymo V column. Centrifuge at 20,000 × g for 1 min at 4°C. Repeat with the remaining 480 μL.
Wash the column by adding 200 μL of 80% ethanol, then centrifuging at 20,000 × g for 1 min at 4°C.
Repeat the wash step twice more (for a total of three washes).
To elute the RNA, add 200 μL of nuclease-free water and spin at 21,000 × g for 2 min at 4°C.
Precipitate the eluted RNA by adding 22 μL of 3 M sodium acetate, pH 5.3 and 1 mL of 100% ethanol.
Incubate at −20°C for 30 min. Centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 30 min to pellet the RNA.
Wash pellets with 1 mL of 80% ethanol and centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 10 min.
Remove supernatant and air-dry pellets at 25°C for 5 min.
Resuspend the precipitated RNA in 6 μL of nuclease-free water.
Transfer 0.5 μL of capped RNA to a tube containing 9.5 μL of water for concentration measurement.
Load 2 μL of diluted RNA onto a Nanodrop and measure the capped RNA concentration.
Determine the molarity of the capped RNA solution using the following approximate molecular weight calculation: Molecular Weight of ssRNA = (number of nucleotides × 320.5) + 159.0.
Transfer 50 pmol of capped RNA to a new 0.2 mL tube. Add water to bring the total volume to 6 μL.

Add 100 μL of phenol:chloroform:IAA, 25:24:1, pH 6.6.
Vortex briefly and centrifuge at 16,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C to separate the phases.
Carefully transfer the top aqueous layer to a new 1.5 mL tube.

Wash pellets with 1 mL of 80% ethanol and centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 10 min. Remove supernatant and repeat for a second wash.
Remove the supernatant and air-dry pellets at 25°C for 5 min.
Resuspend the precipitated RNA in 1.2 mL of nuclease-free water.
Critical: Reserve 60 μL (5%) for pool library preparation.
Yeast extract preparation and ribosome recruitment
Timing: 0.5–1 h
The yeast translation extract is first treated with micrococcal nuclease to degrade endogenous mRNA, increasing ribosome recruitment to the pool RNA. The ribosome recruitment reactions are carried out in the presence of cycloheximide to ensure that each RNA is only able to recruit a single ribosome that is then trapped on that RNA.
Degrade endogenous mRNA from the yeast translation extract by treating with micrococcal nuclease (MNase):
Add 42 μL of 40 mM CaCl2 to 3.5 mL of yeast translation extract.
Critical: Supplementing the extract with CaCl2 is essential as MNase is a Ca2+-dependent enzyme.

Degrade endogenous mRNAs by adding 35 μL of MNase and incubating for 10 min at 25°C on a rotator.
Deactivate the MNase by adding 63 μL of 0.1 M EGTA and transfer to ice.
Critical: The use of EGTA in place of other chelators (i.e., EDTA) is essential. EGTA has a significantly higher affinity for Ca2+ than Mg2+, thus inactivating MNase without significantly perturbing Mg2+-dependent processes.
Prepare the in vitro ribosome recruitment reaction. The amount shown for the 3.2× allows for 3 individual replicate reactions with additional volume to allow for pipetting error.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2163_19.csv
Split each reaction in half by transferring 810 μL to 2 1.5 mL tubes.
Add 190 μL of the capped and biotinylated RNA pool (20 pmol of RNA per tube).
Incubate the reaction for 30 min on a thermomixer set to 600 RPM and 26°C. Immediately place on ice.
Transfer 200 μL of each reaction into a new 1.5 mL tube. Snap-freeze these samples in liquid nitrogen and store at −80°C for subsequent input library preparation.
Isolation of 80S-RNA complexes and RNA extraction
Timing: 8–10 h
In this step, RNAs bound to an 80S ribosome are separated from unbound through sucrose gradient fractionation. Cycloheximide is maintained in the sucrose solutions to ensure 80S-RNA complexes are maintained during fractionation. Hot phenol plus SDS RNA extraction is used to ensure complete denaturation of the concentrated ribosomal RNA and proteins.
Before you begin, pre-chill SW28 rotor and swing buckets to 4°C. Turn on ultracentrifuge and allow it to reach 4°C.
Prepare the sucrose gradients. This is done using a Biocomp Gradient Master/Fractionator station and associated parts and accessories.
Begin by preparing 10% and 50% sucrose solutions.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2163_20.csv
Using the Marker Block, mark the long cap halfway point of Seton Polyclear ultracentrifuge tubes.

Add the 10% sucrose solution until approximately 1 cm above the mark.
Draw 60 mL of 50% sucrose solution into a 60 mL syringe.
Affix a wide-bore pipetting needle to the syringe.
Depress the plunger until the solution is at the end of the needle, then hold tension to prevent dripping. Insert the needle to the bottom of the tube containing 10% sucrose.
Slowly dispense the 50% sucrose solution until the interface reaches the marked point. Hold tension on the syringe to prevent dripping and remove from the tube.
Repeat the underlaying process for the remaining tubes.
Place the long caps on the filled tubes, avoiding bubbles, and remove any excess solution from the top of the cap.
Place the tubes in the Magnabase holder, then place the holder onto the Gradient Master mixing station.
Select the pre-installed program for the SW28 10%–50% sucrose gradient (long) and run the gradient preparation.
Place the prepared gradients in SW28 buckets and chill at 4°C for 30 min.
Slowly remove the caps and then gently load the 1.8 mL ribosome recruitment reaction onto the top of the gradient.
Precisely balance the swing buckets and spin the gradients for 3 h at 27,000 RPM (approximately 97,000 × g) at 4°C.
Fractionate the sucrose gradients using a Gradient Master with a fraction collector attached.
Note: An example gradient trace is shown in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
Collect fraction tubes corresponding to the 80S fraction. Pool the 80S fractions in 15 mL conical tubes. Keep on ice.

80S: Centrifuge at 23,500 × g for 20 min at 4°C. Input: Centrifuge at 21,000 × g for 20 min at 4°C.

Air dry the pellets for 5 min on ice. Resuspend 80S and input samples in 500 μL of streptavidin binding buffer and proceed immediately to streptavidin pulldown.
Isolation of pool RNA
Timing: 1.5 days
The RNA extracted from the 80S fraction contains a large amount of contaminating ribosomal RNA. In this step, the biotinylated RNA pool is pulled down with streptavidin beads to remove this contamination from subsequent library preparation steps. The reserved RNA pool and input samples are also pulled down to account for potential biases in pull-down efficiency.
Briefly vortex the magnetic streptavidin beads to resuspend. Transfer 125 μL of bead slurry per sample to a LoBind 1.5 mL tube.
Apply the tubes to a magnetic rack to separate the beads for 30 s. Remove the supernatant. Equilibrate the beads by washing the beads twice with 100 μL of streptavidin binding buffer.
Denature the RNA samples by incubating at 65°C for 5 min. Transfer to ice for 3 min.
Transfer the RNA samples to the tubes containing the magnetic beads. Vortex briefly to mix. Incubate the samples for 12–14 h at 4°C, rotating.
Apply the tubes to the magnetic rack and allow to separate for 2 min. Remove the supernatant. Wash the samples three times with 1 mL of streptavidin wash buffer.
To elute, resuspend the beads in 50 μL of streptavidin elution buffer. Incubate at 70°C for 5 min.
Apply the tubes to the magnetic rack and transfer the eluted RNA to new 1.5 mL tubes.
Add 400 μL of water, 50 μL of 3 M sodium acetate pH 5.3, 2 μL of Glycoblue, and 600 μL of isopropanol. Incubate the samples at −20°C for at least 30 min to precipitate RNA.

Pause point: The purified RNA can be stored at −20°C in isopropanol until ready for use.
Centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 30 min to pellet the RNA.
Wash pellets twice with 1 mL of 80% ethanol and centrifuge at 21,000 × g at 4°C for 10 min.
Remove supernatant and air-dry pellets at 25°C for 5 min.
Resuspend the RNA in 11 μL of water and proceed immediately to reverse transcription.
Reverse transcription and adaptor ligation
Timing: 2–3 days
Here, the purified RNA is reverse transcribed into single-stranded cDNA. We gel-purify full-length cDNA to capture only the desired product for subsequent steps. An adaptor containing a common PCR handle and a 10N randomer unique molecular identifier (UMI) sequence for PCR duplicate collapsing is then ligated to the 3′ end of the cDNA. The adaptor ligation reactions are then cleaned up using Silane beads.
Transfer the resuspended RNA to PCR tubes for RT primer annealing.
Add 1 μL of 10 μM RT primer to the resuspended RNA.
Transfer the samples to a thermocycler. Denature the RNA and anneal the RT primer with the following program:

Transfer the samples to ice.
Prepare the Superscript III reverse transcription master mix as follows:

Add 8 μL of RT master mix to each tube containing RNA. Incubate at 50°C for 1 h.
Add 2 μL of 1 M sodium hydroxide to each sample. Incubate at 98°C for 15 min to degrade the RNA. Neutralize by adding 2 μL of 1 M hydrochloric acid.
Add 22 μL of formamide loading buffer and denature the cDNA at 70°C for 5 min.
Load the samples onto an 8% denaturing TBE polyacrylamide mini gel.

Run the gel at 200 V for 45 min.
Remove the gel from the plate and stain by covering in 15 mL of 0.5× TBE plus 2 μL of SYBR Gold.

Visualize under blue light.

Diagnostic PCRs, library construction, and quality control
Timing: 1.5 days

These steps prepare next-generation sequencing libraries from the adaptor-ligated cDNA samples. The PCR primers used provide Illumina adaptor sequences with the reverse primer including a sample-specific 6-nucleotide barcode for sample identification. In the first step, we run small-scale diagnostic PCRs across a range of PCR cycles to identify the optimal cycle number for library construction without producing spurious overamplification products and large numbers of PCR duplicates. With the optimal cycle number identified, we run full-scale library construction PCRs and gel-purify the library products. The libraries are then quantified on Qubit and run on a Bioanalyzer to check library purity.

Note: We generally recommend testing at least 3 cycle numbers ranging from 10 – 20 cycles as a first pass. Libraries requiring more than 20 cycles may be sequenced but are likely to contain large numbers of PCR duplicates that hinder analysis.
Run the diagnostic PCRs on 8% non-denaturing TBE polyacrylamide mini gels at 200 V for 45 min in 0.5× TBE.
Remove the gels from the plates and stain by covering in 15 mL of 0.5× TBE plus 2 μL of SYBR Gold.
Incubate at 25°C on a rocking platform for 5 min.
Visualize under blue light.
